bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Lieutenant Governor in Council to refer matters to court
bcl:section.bcl:text:
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may refer any matter to the Court of Appeal or to
        the Supreme Court for hearing and consideration, and the Court of Appeal or the Supreme
        Court must then hear and consider it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court must give to the Lieutenant Governor in
          Council its opinion on the matter referred, with reasons, in the manner of a judgment in
          an ordinary action.

A justice of the Court of Appeal who differs from the opinion of the majority may
          give to the Lieutenant Governor in Council the justice's opinion, with reasons.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice to Attorney General of Canada
bcl:section.bcl:text:
In case the matter referred relates to the constitutional validity of all or part of
        an Act, the Attorney General of Canada must be notified of the hearing, and must be heard if
        the Attorney General of Canada sees fit.

bcl:text.#text:
On a reference by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under the agreement made
        between the government of British Columbia and the government of Canada under the
           (Canada), the Attorney General
        of Canada and the Attorney General of any province of Canada that has, after December 1,
        1961, entered into a similar agreement must be notified of the hearing, and may appear and
        be heard as a party.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court may direct that a person interested, or, if
        there is a class of persons interested, any one or more persons as representatives of that
        class, must be notified of the hearing, and those persons are entitled to be
        heard.

The opinion of the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court is a judgment of the Court
        of Appeal or of the Supreme Court, as the case may be, and an appeal lies from it in the
        manner of a judgment in an ordinary action.

The reasons given by the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court under this Act must,
        as soon as practicable, be published in the Gazette.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The notice must be served at least 14 days before the day of argument unless the
          court authorizes a shorter notice.

If in a cause, matter or other proceeding to which this section applies the
          Attorney General of British Columbia appears, the Attorney General is a party and, for the
          purpose of an appeal from an adjudication respecting the validity or applicability of a
          law, or respecting entitlement to a constitutional remedy, has the same rights as any
          other party.

If in a cause, matter or other proceeding to which this section applies the
          Attorney General of Canada appears, the Attorney General of Canada is a party and, for the
          purpose of an appeal from an adjudication respecting the validity or applicability of a
          law, or respecting entitlement to a constitutional remedy, has the same rights as any
          other party.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Action for declaration of validity of Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Supreme Court has jurisdiction to entertain an action at the instance of
          either the Attorney General of Canada or the Attorney General of British Columbia for a
          declaration as to the validity of an Act of the Legislature, though no further relief is
          sought.

The action is sufficiently constituted if the 2 Attorneys General are
          parties.

An appeal lies from the judgment in the manner of a judgment in an ordinary
          action.
